<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases"> <x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"> <common_name>Coryneum blight (Shot hole disease)</common_name> <description>How coryneum blight (Wilsonomyces corpophilus) occurs? The fungal pathogen primarily occurs through the dispersal of fungal spores. It infects plants through wounds or natural openings such as stomata on the leaves. Spores of the fungus are spread by wind, rain, or through contact with infected plant material. Once the spores land on susceptible plants, they germinate and penetrate the plant tissues, establishing an infection. Warm temperatures, high humidity, and excessive moisture promote its growth.
</description> <family/> <host>peach,</host> <number>PLD0001012</number> <scientific_name>Wilsonomyces carpophilus</scientific_name> <solution>Chemical Control Here are some commonly available fungicides for treating Coryneum blight (Wilsonomyces carpophilus)
• Armada 50 WDG: Contains trifloxystrobin and triadimefon (Group 3 + 11).
• Bonide Fung-onil Multi-purpose Fungicide: Contains chlorothalonil (Group M5). • Eagle 20 EW: Contains myclobutanil (Group 3).
• Protect DF: Contains mancozeb (Group M3). Always follow label instructions and consult local experts for specific recommendations and availability in your area.
</solution> <sys_class_name>x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases</sys_class_name> <sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by> <sys_created_on>2024-10-21 23:05:49</sys_created_on> <sys_id>a32d160f975112109790fefce053af9c</sys_id> <sys_mod_count>0</sys_mod_count> <sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by> <sys_updated_on>2024-10-21 23:05:49</sys_updated_on> </x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases> </record_update>
